annotation.TEXT: With that done, let's move on to Propeller Knight's stage. The Flying Machine is easily one of the most difficult levels in the entire game, so I suppose it could be seen as a good thing to get it out of the way as soon as possible. Additionally, as a few had pointed out in the reasoning for their votes, this stage also holds one of the must useful relics in the game as well.

As per the poll on the previous segment, the next set of main stages have been decided on: Propeller Knight was the overall winner with 6 votes in his favor, followed by Tinker Knight with 3, and Polar Knight with 1. Before I move though, I figured it'd be best to quickly show off the extra stage I forgot to include in the previous segment. Knuckler's Quarry is similar to the Forest of Phasing in that it revolves around the use of a relic - specifically the Dust Knuckles - to get through the stage.

...And apparently, much like what happened with Mr. Hat: Any time I say a boss is difficult, they immediately become easy. Although I like how this fight came out, I'm a bit disappointed I couldn't show off some of his other moves (such as aforementioned bombs, which he can use his propeller to blow them into you or reel them in).

Fittingly enough, Propeller Knight is among the most difficult of the main bosses. Aside from being rather quick, he has several moves at his disposal - some of which can be used in reaction to your own motions (bouncing off him too many times will cause him to launch you up into the air, and then stab you when you come back down). He also calls in an airship once he's down to half-health, which can launch out bombs and destroy the platform.

This right here has got to be one of the most annoying enemies in the entire game. It's basically a mobile version of the Fan Fiend from Mega Man 2, whose only method of "attacking" is to throw off your movements by blowing you back into hazards (or, more likely than not, right off the edge of the screen).

Chester will sell you the Propeller Dagger for 4,000 gold in this level. Going along with more Mega Man references (at least on my part, anyways), the Propeller Dagger is a bit like the Comet Dash. It sends you flying forward as a way to get over large gaps much easier. The dagger itself can also hurt enemies or break blocks by running into them, but the dash will be cancelled and Shovel Knight will bounce back a bit after hitting them (this can also happen if you run into a wall as well).

Worst part of the level (at least, in my opinion). The air currents here constantly change, which can easily kill you if your timing is a bit off. It's not as bad as...oh say, the damned bramble and wind section from Animal Antics, but there's still more than a few ways to mess this part up and accidentally get launched into the spikes.

The blue versions of these flying jellyfish generate electricity, which can hurt you if you come into contact with them (even if you attempt to down-thrust on them). They tend to be paired with several air currents and falling platforms that make up the main gimmicks of these stages. Thankfully, said platforms actually respawn once you leave a room and come back.
